awd_titl_txt: Hominid Dental Metagenomes for Pathogen Evolution Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Dental cavities and periodontal disease, both major oral health problems in today’s world, are caused by opportunistic bacterial pathogens found in the mouth. This project focuses on the evolutionary history of these pathogens, examining how the genomes of oral pathogens differ across a comparative sample of primate species, and, within humans, how they are impacted by changes in dietary practices, geographic space, and time. Through this comparative research and the study of oral pathogen genomes recovered from ancient human populations, this project advances knowledge about pathogen evolution in humans over thousands of years and provides further insight into the relationships between host behavior and pathogen evolution. The project benefits from a team-science approach that involves close collaboration, as well as academic attribution, for descendent communities of the ancient human populations being studied. Project findings are communicated to these communities through public talks focusing on the impact of oral disease, contextualized by microbiome research. The project also contributes to the professional development of researchers through online workshops focusing on ancient microbiome data analysis, supports open science by publication in open-access journals and sharing data through public repositories, and promotes the broader participation of women in STEM through student training and mentoring activities.

The transition from a hunter-gatherer to an agricultural lifestyle, as well as the advent of industrialization, are thought to have increased the prevalence of oral disease in humans. However, the way that these transitions affected oral pathogens at a genomic level, especially in terms of their diversity and virulence, have not been fully characterized. Additionally, the broader primate comparative context of oral pathogen diversity is not well understood. In this project, the investigators reconstruct oral pathogen genomes from dental calculus, a calcified form of dental plaque. Dental calculus is known to preserve biomolecules for thousands of years and provides a wealth of information regarding the host, oral bacteria, and diet. Calculus samples are collected from museum specimens of nonhuman primates (chimpanzees, gorillas, and orangutans), and from ancient human populations from the continents of Africa and the Americas. From both continents, samples are retrieved from the same geographic location but from time periods associated with different dietary strategies (hunter-gatherer versus agriculture). The investigators use state-of-the-art ancient DNA protocols, metagenomic sequencing, and target enrichment strategies to generate high-quality genome data for oral pathogens found in these samples. These genome data provide a nuanced understanding of the evolutionary relationships between oral pathogen strains affecting different host species, and how oral pathogen strain diversity and genomic architecture have changed over time and space.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Oral diseases, such as caries (tooth decay) and periodontitis (severe gum disease), afflict nearly half of the global population. These oral diseases are caused by perturbations in the oral microbiome composition, leading to the proliferation of opportunistically pathogenic microbes. It is traditionally thought that oral disease prevalence has increased over the course of human history, as human populations transitioned from a hunter-gatherer to an agriculture-based diet and lifestyle. This project aimed to study oral pathogen evolution by determining how oral microbial genetic diversity and gene content differ depending upon factors such as host species, dietary lifestyle, and geographic and temporal context.

Using state-of-the-art ancient DNA and next-generation sequencing technologies, this project recovered oral microbiomes from ancient human individuals spanning a period of nearly 8,000 years. Briefly, DNA was recovered from non-invasively sampled archaeological dental calculus (tartar) samples using protocols optimized for ancient DNA recovery, processed into double-stranded DNA libraries, and shotgun-sequenced using Illumina technology. The resulting metagenomic data were analyzed using bioinformatics workflows to authenticate recovery of ancient oral microbiomes, generate taxonomic and functional microbial profiles, reconstruct genomes of oral microbes, and assess strain relationships and gene content. Nearly 450 dental calculus samples from diverse archaeological contexts were sequenced over the course of this project.

To understand how dietary transitions impacted oral pathogen genomes, we analyzed oral microbiomes from ancient human populations from the same geographical location but different temporal contexts, each associated with a different dietary lifestyle. These included individuals from Nubia (from Sudan) and ancestral Maya from Belize. The dental calculus samples from Nubian individuals did not yield ancient oral microbiomes due to poor DNA preservation. We generated oral microbiomes from 24 ancestral Maya individuals spanning a time-period of nearly 8,000 years during which these populations transitioned to a diet comprising maize as a dietary staple. Comparing the oral microbiomes of pre-maize and staple-maize individuals, we found that an oral commensal Pseudoramibacter alactolyticus was highly abundant among the pre-maize individuals and served as a major contributor to carbohydrate metabolism. In staple-maize individuals, more number of species contributed to carbohydrate metabolism; these included Streptococcus species, some of which are linked to caries. Overall, our analyses show that the transition to a carbohydrate-rich diet led to taxonomic and functional changes in the oral microbiome of ancestral Maya individuals.

To understand oral pathogen evolution in the context of human history, we generated ancient oral microbiomes from several human populations pre-dating the era of European colonization in the Americas. These included Wichita Ancestors from Oklahoma, Ohlone Ancestors from California, and ancient and modern-day Amazonian individuals from Brazil. We reconstructed the genomes of oral bacteria such as Tannerella forsythia and Pseudoramibacter alactolyticus. We determined that different oral microbes show distinct evolutionary histories. For example, the oral commensal Pseudoramibacter alactolyticus showed long-term lineage continuity in the Americas, whereas the oral pathogen Tannerella forsythia showed potential lineage replacement after European Contact. Our analyses also highlighted the lack of reference genome data for oral microbes and underscore the need for widespread sequencing of oral microbiomes from diverse modern populations.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in our increased understanding of oral microbial evolution in the context of human bioculture. We also generated hundreds of ancient oral metagenomes which will serve as a rich resource to other researchers, including the largest ancient metagenome dataset from a single American population. Ongoing and future analyses of these data may reveal interesting insights into the functional potential of these oral pathogens and the corresponding impact on oral disease. 

The broader impacts of this project included the development of a training program in ancient metagenomics for molecular anthropology researchers. Over the course of this project, five faculty-level researchers, two post-doctoral researchers, six graduate students (including a Fulbright Scholar from Brazil), and one undergraduate student were trained in ancient DNA and metagenomics workflows at the Laboratory of Molecular Anthropology and Microbiome Research (LMAMR), University of Oklahoma. We communicated research findings to our stakeholder communities along with conducting place-based health outreach highlighting the importance of oral health and hygiene in local languages. Our research findings were published in open-access peer-reviewed manuscripts and also presented at several scientific conferences including those sponsored by the American Association of Biological Anthropologists, the Society for American Archaeology, the International Society for Biomolecular Archaeology, the Plant and Animal Genomes Meeting, and the Society for Molecular Biology and Evolution.
